May 21, 1957
Dr. Burton Paulu
President
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
Station KUOM
University of Minnesota
Minneapolis, Minnesota
Dear Burton:
Thank you for your kind letter and for the enclosures
regarding your facilities and budget.
Let me take this opportunity to advise you regarding the
meeting of the Associate Members Committee (in this case Gerald
Willsea and myself), and the discussion we had regarding not associate
but individual members. First of all, Willses reacted very badly to
the presentation of the individual membership solicitation plea at the
luncheon. I had had this same reaction, but I an so acutely sensitive
to these things that I had put it down simply to that. This was not the
major problem, however. The major problem was how Willsea, or
anyone else, could justify to his staff the notion that members should
become individual NAEB members, . He suggested that we prepare
a carefully worked out pitch showing the advantages accruing to
individual members; that we plan, in association with regional and
perhaps even smaller meetings, ways in which individual members
could get together with officers from President down to Chairman of
the Individual Members Committee. We agreed that what the Profes¬
sional Advancement Committee was currently working on would be of
very great interest to the individual member^, and thought that perhaps
there might be some special mailings to individual members regarding
professional advancement problems and opportunities.
We realized, of course, that this was none of our Committee's
business, but we were perfectly hap; y w th the state of the associate mem¬
bers and got on the state of individual members quite by accident. If any
of the above seems useful to you. I'm Bure you will know what to do with
it; and if it doesn't, it can easily be dropped into the wastebasket.
